subject: Ethics
title: Lying to Spare Feelings
description: A quick win: understand Lying to Spare Feelings.

hook.text: Your friend asks if their terrible painting is good. You know the truth will crush them. Do you lie?

buildup.text: Kant said lying is always wrongâ€”even to spare feelings. The truth is a duty regardless of consequences.

discovery.text: Utilitarians disagree: if a small lie prevents real suffering and causes no harm, it's the kind thing to do.

twist.text: But lies compound. Your friend enters a contest, loses badly, and finds out everyone lied. Now the hurt is worse.

climax.text: The real question isn't truth or kindness. It's whether you're lying for them or for your own comfort.

punchline.text: Most 'kind' lies protect the liar, not the listener.

quiz.question: What is Kant's position on lying to spare someone's feelings?
options: Small lies are acceptable when they prevent suffering
Lying is always wrong, regardless of consequencesâ€”truth is a duty
Lying is permissible if both parties agree to the deception
